title: Department of Defense support for TV series "Did They Fix That?"

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to collaboration between the Department of Defense (DoD) and the production of the TV series "Did They Fix That?" (2023-). Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of DoD and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Did They Fix That?," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

"Did They Fix That?" appears on a list of DoD entertainment industry collaborations released to me through FOIA. The list is attached to this request.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation as well as the editor-in-chief and a contributor to a research magazine published by said foundation titled "Cultural Engineering Studies." These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: RFK Meeting and Communications with Ed Martin

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any audio recordings, video recordings, or transcripts of the March 18, 2025, meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

2. Any notes taken during the March 18, 2025, meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

3. Any memoranda, summaries, or minutes concerning the March 18, 2025, meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

4. All documents, communications, emails, calendar invitations, scheduling notes, agendas, briefing materials, or background documents prepared in advance of, or related to, planning and arranging the March 18 meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

5. All written communications, including emails, letters, or messages, between the Office of the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Office of the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia on or after January 20, 2025.

6. Any communications, emails, memoranda, or other documents within HHS that reference or discuss the March 18, 2025, meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

7. Any written materials exchanged during (or referenced in any agenda for) the March 18, 2025, meeting involving Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and Acting U.S. Attorney Ed Martin.

8. Any communications to or from Andrew Nixon referencing "Ed Martin" or the Office of the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Request to FBI for all communications with author Thomas Harris

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All communications between the FBI and Thomas Harris (born William Thomas Harris III, on September 22, 1940, in Jackson, Tennessee), author of "Silence of the Lambs," within the records retention schedule(s) of the relevant office(s). Such communications may include, but should not be limited to, emails, correspondence, memos, and transcriptions of telephone calls. 

A previous request from me was rejected by the FBI on the grounds that it would violate Mr. Harris's personal privacy to even acknowledge the existence of such records. As I wrote in my appeal, which was never processed, I do not think this provision applies to my request. To show this, I will first limit the scope of my request to communications between Mr. Harris and the FBI to those communications which are relevant to Mr. Harris's professional work as a writer and novelist. Such communications could not involve a reasonable expectation that they would not be subject to FOIA. Furthermore, even if certain third-party communications are not subject to FOIA, the FBI's own written communications are still subject to FOIA, and my request includes communications from the FBI.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Request for the Navy personnel file for David L. Marston

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request for the Navy personnel file for David L. Marston
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the U.S. Navy personnel records (OMPF) for a former servicemember named DAVID LOUIS MARSON (DATE OF BIRTH: 01/23/1974). Mr. Marston was born in Baltimore, Maryland. According to online sources, he served in the U.S. Navy for 4 1/2 years beginning around 2002 and served as a Master at Arms. The requested records include performance reports, job assessments, disciplinary records, training received, discharge papers, and any other releasable records.

Mr. Marston is an actor and DJ, and he has appeared in a string of major films, including "Iron Man 2" and "The Avengers." During the time that he was apparently in the Navy, he also appeared in at least one film supported by the Navy, namely, the 2006 movie "Annapolis." The public interest in Mr. Marston should favor disclosure of many of these records, particularly in relation to any disciplinary records, should those records exist.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo
